segments.key_quote: What is the cause for his dissatisfaction? That's clearly answered by Narada.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on Vyasa Deva's dissatisfaction despite compiling Vedic literature and how Narada Muni instructed him to compile Srimad Bhagavatam, which exclusively glorifies Krishna.
segments.transcript: This is almost the concluding portion of this chapter. This was spoken by Narada in response to a question by Vyasa Deva. Vyasa Deva, after compiling the varieties of Vedic literature, he was somehow feeling dissatisfaction in his heart that he had not done enough for the welfare of the people. So, just at the time when he was contemplating what was the cause of his dissatisfaction, that's exactly when Narada Muni arrived in his ashram, in Vyasa's ashram. So, Vyasa received Narada very respectfully and inquired from him, what is the cause of my dissatisfaction? So, then Narada Muni pointed out, even though you have compiled so many varieties of Vedic literature, you have not compiled one particular literature which exclusively glorifies Krishna, the Supreme Personality of Godhood. And Vyasa Deva was instructed by Narada to compile that particular literature. So, Narada gave instructions to Vyasa Deva how to go about compiling the Srimad Bhagavatam, which is the exclusive literature glorifying Krishna, the Supreme Personality of Godhead. Now not only did Vyasa get instructions about compiling Bhagavatam but he also inquired from Narada about his own self-realization and that is what Narada has explained. How did he become self-realized? How did he become the great devotee Narada? So the whole history has been described. I have explained my birth and activities for self-realization as you asked. So whatever Vyasa Dev asked, Narada has described. Now Vyasa Dev is being told by Narada, all this will be conducive for your personal satisfaction also. So Vyasa Dev was looking for a clue. What is the cause for his dissatisfaction? That's clearly answered by Narada.

segments.summary: The speaker explains how Narada's devotional service began in his previous life as the son of a maidservant through association with sages and partaking of their remnants (prasadam), leading to purification and attraction to Krishna katha.
segments.transcript: So all these have been explained in brief, of course, by Narada to Vyasa. So Prabhupada is further explained. Narada has explained how the seeds of devotional service were sown by the transcendental association, and how they gradually developed by hearing the sages, the bhaktivedantas who happened to be passing by that place where Narada in his previous life as the son of a maidservant was staying with his mother. And the sages happened to stop by in that spot, and Narada's mother was rendering some menial service to the sages, and Narada as a small boy joined his mother. And one day he took some remnants of some food left behind by the sages, the bhaktivedantas, and that resulted in his purification and he became attracted to the subject matter of krishna katha which they were discussing. From those self-realized sages was detachment from worldliness so much so that even a small boy could receive the death news of his mother who was his only caretaker as the blessings of God. The boy became enlightened in their association by hearing them after he partook remnants of uh prasadam left behind by them so it had a very big transformation of his heart the small boy narada in his previous life as a small boy and at once he took the opportunity to search out the lord.

segments.key_quote: We have to re-establish our lost relationship with Krishna that is the whole practice of bhakti
segments.summary: The speaker describes Narada's search for the Lord, the brief darshan he received, and how devotional service helps one get rid of the reactions of fruitive activities, breaking the cycle of birth and death.
segments.transcript: We have to re-establish our lost relationship with Krishna, that is the whole practice of bhakti, that is what bhakti is meant for. So this boy went for searching the Lord exactly as he had been instructed by those sages, the bhaktivedantas. A sincere urge for having an interview with the Lord was also granted to him, although it is not possible for anyone to see the Lord with mundane eyes. Krishna gave him brief darshan and afterwards Narada tried to have the darshan again and he could not, but the Lord spoke to Narada to encourage him to continue his practice of meditation on the Supreme Lord in the heart as taught by the bhaktivedantas. So Naramuni also explained to Vyasa Deva how by execution of pure transcendental service one can get rid of the fruitive action of accumulated work. We have been doing so many material activities in contact with this material world, contact with the three modes and that has resulted in so many reactions and those reactions result in a repetition of birth and death in this world. We cannot get out of material existence but pure devotional service helps us to completely clear away all these reactions.
